Hi folks! I'm currently going through MIL, in particular, this exercise. I've done it once based on the sorrys in the book text, but now I'm trying to redo it from scratch so that I can properly understand the proof.

I've decided to start formalizing this version of the proof instead of the one in MIL which I found slightly more intuitive and which seems to be very close but with some internal definitions flipped around.

I haven't gotten to injectivity yet but here is my proof of surjectivity of h:

import Mathlib

open Set
open Function

noncomputable section
open Classical
variable {α β : Type*} [Nonempty β]

section

variable (f : α → β) (g : β → α)

def lonelyPointsIter: ℕ → Set β
  | 0 => univ \ f '' univ
  | n + 1 => f '' (g '' (lonelyPointsIter n))

def lonelyPoints :=
  ⋃ i, lonelyPointsIter f g i

def h (x : α) : β :=
  if f x ∈ lonelyPoints f g then (invFun g) x else f x

theorem b_lonely_imp_fgb_lonely {b: β} (hb : b ∈ lonelyPoints f g) : f (g b) ∈ lonelyPoints f g := by
  simp only [lonelyPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
  have ⟨i, b_lonely_at_i⟩ := hb
  use i + 1
  simp only [lonelyPointsIter]
  use g b
  rw [mem_image]
  constructor
  · use b
  rfl

theorem b_not_lonely_imp_b_eq_fa {b: β} (hb : b ∉ lonelyPoints f g) : ∃ a, (f a) = b := by
  simp only [lonelyPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
  contrapose! hb
  use 0
  rw [lonelyPointsIter]
  constructor
  · trivial
  rw [mem_image]
  push_neg
  intro x _
  exact hb x

theorem sb_surjective (hg : Injective g) : Surjective (h f g) := by
  intro b
  by_cases is_b_lonely : b ∈ lonelyPoints f g
  · have fgb_lonely := b_lonely_imp_fgb_lonely f g is_b_lonely
    simp only [h]
    use g b
    rw [if_pos fgb_lonely]
    apply leftInverse_invFun hg
  · have ⟨a, ha⟩ := b_not_lonely_imp_b_eq_fa f g is_b_lonely
    simp only [h]
    use a
    rw [ha, if_neg is_b_lonely]

theorem sb_injective (hf : Injective f) : Injective (h f g) := by
  intro x1 x2 heq
  sorry -- TODO

theorem schroeder_bernstein {f : α → β} {g : β → α} (hf : Injective f) (hg : Injective g) :
    ∃ h : α → β, Bijective h :=
  ⟨h f g, sb_injective f g hf, sb_surjective f g hg⟩

end

I would appreciate any comments on the style, tactics used, whether I could make things shorter (in a way that doesn't hurt readability) or more conventional. Is the MIL version of the proof strictly better in terms of style? Is there something in particular it's doing that's better?

Thanks!

I think Set.range f might be preferable to f '' univ (but I could be wrong, and it likely doesn't matter here)

it might be even cleaner to do (Set.range f)ᶜ instead of univ \ Set.range f

Using (Set.range f)ᶜ in your definition of lonelyPointsIter, this theorem can be shortened a bit:

theorem b_not_lonely_imp_b_eq_fa {b: β} (hb : b ∉ lonelyPoints f g) : ∃ a, (f a) = b := by
  simp only [lonelyPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
  contrapose! hb
  use 0
  rw [lonelyPointsIter, mem_compl_iff, mem_range]
  push_neg
  exact hb
The advantage of Set.range is that you don't get a spurious x \in univ in your terms. The advantage of compl is that there's more API

I see that the MIL chapter Dan is going through uses univ \ g '' univ in a similar proof... perhaps it's like that because it's trying to keep things conceptually simple for beginners, but it could be a good place to introduce Set.range and compl if they haven't been introduced already
huh, earlier in the same chapter it says "range f is provably equal to f '' univ" so I'm not sure why they went with g '' univ later on

one other comment: when using nested Set.images, I've found that it can sometimes be simpler to convert it to a single Set.image using function composition

in this case, you could define the n + 1 case of lonelyPointsIter as (f ∘ g) '' (lonelyPointsIter n)

with that change, I was able to shave a few lines off of b_lonely_imp_fgb_lonely:

theorem b_lonely_imp_fgb_lonely {b: β} (hb : b ∈ lonelyPoints f g) : f (g b) ∈ lonelyPoints f g := by
  simp only [lonelyPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
  have ⟨i, b_lonely_at_i⟩ := hb
  use i + 1
  rw [lonelyPointsIter, mem_image]
  use b, b_lonely_at_i
  rw [comp_apply]

Thanks! Having finished this proof, I realized that the approach in the book (where the "lonely points" are defined in terms of A rather than B) may be a bit less annoying. So I'm doing another iteration from scratch, this time closer to how the book is doing it. I'm also trying to keep the code shorter and avoid extra lemmas.

For posterity, this is what I have so far and am happy with:

import Mathlib

open Set
open Function

noncomputable section
open Classical
variable {α β : Type*} [Nonempty β]

section

variable (f : α → β) (g : β → α)

def directIter: ℕ → Set α
  | 0 => (Set.range g)ᶜ
  | n + 1 => (g ∘ f) '' (directIter n)

def directPoints :=
  ⋃ i, directIter f g i

def h (x : α) : β :=
  if x ∈ directPoints f g then f x else (invFun g) x

theorem sb_surjective (injg : Injective g) : Surjective (h f g) := by
  intro b
  unfold h
  by_cases gb_direct : g b ∈ directPoints f g
  · /- If g(b) is a part of a direct chain, it must have been added
    to the direct set via some a -(f)-> b -(g)-> g(b) iteration.
    By picking that a, we get h(a) = f(a) = b, proving b is reachable. -/
    simp only [directPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
    rcases gb_direct with ⟨n, hn⟩
    rcases n with _ | n
    · tauto
    rcases hn with ⟨a, a_direct, ha⟩
    use a
    rw [if_pos (by use n)]
    exact injg ha
  /- If g(b) is not a part of some direct chain [1], pick a := g(b).
  For that a, h(a) =(by [1])= inv_g(a) =(by def.)= inv_g(g(b)).
  Thus, proving inv_g(g(b)) = b would be enough to show b is reachable.
  To cancel them out, we'll wrap both sides with g (thanks, injectivity). -/
  use g b
  rw [if_neg gb_direct]
  apply injg
  apply invFun_eq
  use b

theorem sb_injective (hf : Injective f) : Injective (h f g) := by
  sorry

theorem schroeder_bernstein {f : α → β} {g : β → α} (hf : Injective f) (hg : Injective g) :
    ∃ h : α → β, Bijective h :=
  ⟨h f g, sb_injective f g hf, sb_surjective f g hg⟩

end

Still need to work on injectivity.

one minor stylistic comment: when I do something that splits the goal into 2 separate goals (as opposed to just adding a side goal), I'll usually indent both branches, as I feel that it makes the structure of the proof more obvious

Alright, here's my finished version (including injectivity). I'm pretty happy with this one. I also feel like I understood the mechanics of the proof pretty well this time.

Hopefully this looks good!

import Mathlib

open Set
open Function

noncomputable section
open Classical
variable {α β : Type*} [Nonempty β]

section

variable (f : α → β) (g : β → α)

def directIter: ℕ → Set α
  | 0 => (Set.range g)ᶜ
  | n + 1 => (g ∘ f) '' (directIter n)

def directPoints :=
  ⋃ i, directIter f g i

def h (x : α) : β :=
  if x ∈ directPoints f g then f x else (invFun g) x

theorem sb_surjective (injg : Injective g) : Surjective (h f g) := by
  intro b
  unfold h
  by_cases gb_direct : g b ∈ directPoints f g
  · /- If g(b) is a part of a direct chain, it must have been added
    to the direct set via some a -(f)-> b -(g)-> g(b) iteration.
    By picking that a, we get h(a) = f(a) = b, proving b is reachable. -/
    simp only [directPoints, mem_iUnion] at *
    rcases gb_direct with ⟨n, hn⟩
    rcases n with _ | n
    · tauto
    · rcases hn with ⟨a, a_direct, ha⟩
      use a
      rw [if_pos (by use n)]
      exact injg ha
  /- If g(b) is not a part of some direct chain [1], pick a := g(b).
  For that a, h(a) =(by [1])= inv_g(a) =(by def.)= inv_g(g(b)).
  Thus, proving inv_g(g(b)) = b would be enough to show b is reachable.
  To cancel them out, we'll wrap both sides with g (thanks, injectivity). -/
  use g b
  rw [if_neg gb_direct]
  apply injg
  apply invFun_eq
  use b

theorem g_right_inv {a : α} (ha : a ∉ directPoints f g) : g (invFun g a) = a := by
  /- If a is not a part of the direct chain, it must have been excluded
  when the set was originally being constructed. The elements that were
  excluded were the elements reachable via g. So a must be reachable via g. -/
  have : ∃ b, g b = a := by
    simp only [directPoints, mem_iUnion] at ha
    contrapose! ha
    use 0
    simp only [directIter, mem_compl_iff, mem_range]
    tauto
  apply invFun_eq this

theorem heq_imp_same_directness {a1 a2 : α} (ha1 : a1 ∈ directPoints f g) (heq : h f g a1 = h f g a2) : a2 ∈ directPoints f g := by
  /- If h(a1) = h(a2), either both must be direct or neither is. To see this, we'll unfold
  the definition of h. If one was g^-1(a1) but the other was f(a2), a1 and a2 would be only
  one f->g hop away from each other, forcing both a1 and a2 to be direct (a contradiction). -/
  simp only [h] at *
  rw [if_pos ha1] at heq
  by_cases ha2 : a2 ∈ directPoints f g
  · tauto
  · rw [if_neg ha2] at heq
    simp only [directPoints, mem_iUnion] at ha1
    rcases ha1 with ⟨i, hi⟩
    simp only [directPoints, mem_iUnion]
    use i + 1, a1, hi
    rw [comp_apply, heq]
    apply g_right_inv f g ha2

theorem sb_injective (injf : Injective f) : Injective (h f g) := by
  intro a1 a2 heq
  by_cases a1_direct : a1 ∈ directPoints f g
  · by_cases a2_direct : a2 ∈ directPoints f g
    · rw [h, h, if_pos a1_direct, if_pos a2_direct] at heq
      exact injf heq
    · have := heq_imp_same_directness f g a1_direct heq
      contradiction
  · by_cases a2_direct : a2 ∈ directPoints f g
    · have := heq_imp_same_directness f g a2_direct heq.symm
      contradiction
    · rw [h, h, if_neg a1_direct, if_neg a2_direct] at heq
      have ginv_a1 := g_right_inv f g a1_direct
      have ginv_a2 := g_right_inv f g a2_direct
      rw [← ginv_a1, ← ginv_a2, heq]

theorem schroeder_bernstein {f : α → β} {g : β → α} (hf : Injective f) (hg : Injective g) :
    ∃ h : α → β, Bijective h :=
  ⟨h f g, sb_injective f g hf, sb_surjective f g hg⟩

end
